Investigating the principles, they converge to guide the world. The level path returns to one, and the purpose is measured. How could it not be the case that the true limit is contemplated and attachment to illusory dust is eliminated?

Although the cultivation of giving and precepts is lofty and strict, and the refinement of patience and vigor is harmonious and sharp, they ultimately rely on the real wisdom and take the true scriptures as the path.

In order to open up the confusion of the elephant touch, there is again the assembly at RÄjagá¹›ha. Therefore, illuminating the traces of the five, ascending the first vehicle, discerning the two extremes, penetrating the subtle and rolling up the gaze;
Imitating the four phrases, looking up at the trace of tranquility and concealing the sound.
Cutting off the sprouts of various views, then the flower petals of obscuration fall;
Lifting the net of accumulated doubts, then the clouds of obstruction are removed.
Understanding the emptiness of nature and always cultivating, realizing the falsity of birth and always benefiting, the four demons are thereby confused, and the six pÄramitÄs are thereby gathered.

Giving, which is not wasted, and can give up what is difficult to give up;ğŸ”½Precepts, which are not restrained, and can protect what is difficult to protect;ğŸ”½Forbearance, which is not accepted, and can endure what is unbearable;
Vigor, which is not practiced, and can initiate what is difficult to initiate;
Concentration, which is not still, and the three characteristics do not correspond;
Wisdom, which is not illuminating, and the three wheels do not revolve.
Therefore, if one realizes it, then movement surpasses stillness; if one errs, then stillness becomes more agitated.
The Dharma is neither identical to nor separate from non-dharma; practice is neither the same as nor different from non-practice.
In terms of realization, the true mind is unified in a single contemplation;
In terms of giving rise to it, the Dharma treasures are manifold in myriad ways.

Thus there are two kinds of wisdom, three bodies, four kinds of eloquence, five eyes, six spiritual powers, seven factors of enlightenment, eightfold path, nine concentrations, ten powers, plus the eighteen distinctive abilities, eighty secondary characteristics, twelve links of dependent origination, and twenty kinds of emptiness. They are all formed by the syllable hi and ra, like a collection of jade-like eyebrows, flowing with the teachings of the golden lips.

It is compiled into eight scrolls, originally not a second translation, but I, being unintelligent, mistakenly count myself among the translators. I reminisce about the prosperous feast of the assembly, and lament that those who have passed away cannot receive it. Your kind words of special praise and the inscription of your posthumous voice, originally scattered by the wind of compassion, I will hold it on my head due to the holy vow, and will make the wonderful treasure passed down in the family, and everyone holds the spiritual pearl, washing away the dust of the eight regions, and pouring down the mysterious nourishment for myriad years. May the blessings protect the imperial throne, and the emperor and empress live long;
May the joy extend to the common people, and the Dharma teachings be further propagated.
I hope that those of narrow understanding will shake off their doubts on this frightening day;
And that the arrogant guests will cease their slander at this moment of submission.
If not for those who have served for eons and heard from past generations, how could they open the chapter, abandon their stinginess, forget their words, and enter into appreciation? Alas!

If I can permanently sever my own doubts, afflictions, and bonds, then I will be able to truly explain for all sentient beings the various essential teachings for severing doubts, afflictions, and bonds.

The Buddha told the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva SubhÅ«ti:
You previously asked, 'World-Honored One, you have expounded prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ to the assembly of bodhisattva mahÄsattvas in various places. What is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?' You should know that!

SubhÅ«ti!

The profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be said to be this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, nor can it be said to belong to that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, nor can it be said to be due to that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, nor can it be said to come from that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

Good and brave one!
Wisdom is able to reach far to the true nature of dharmas, therefore it is called prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
The wisdom of the TathÄgata cannot even be attained, let alone attaining prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ!
Good and brave one!
PrajÃ±Ä means understanding all dharmas and knowing all dharmas, therefore it is called prajÃ±Ä.
Good and brave one!
How does prajÃ±Ä understand and know all dharmas?
It means that dharmas are different, and names and words are also different;

However, all dharmas are not apart from names and words. If one understands all dharmas or knows all dharmas, they are both inexpressible. However, in accordance with the understanding of sentient beings, it is said, therefore it is called prajÃ±Ä.
SubhÅ«ti!
PrajÃ±Ä is a provisional designation, and prajÃ±Ä is spoken of due to provisional designation.
However, all dharmas cannot be designated, cannot be moved, cannot be proclaimed, and cannot be manifested. Knowing this is called knowing as it really is.
SubhÅ«ti!
PrajÃ±Ä is neither knowing nor not knowing, neither here nor elsewhere, and is therefore called prajÃ±Ä.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
PrajÃ±Ä is the domain of wisdom, not the domain of non-wisdom, and is neither the domain of non-wisdom nor the domain of wisdom, because wisdom is far removed from all domains.
If wisdom were the domain, it would then not be wisdom. Wisdom does not arise from non-wisdom, nor does wisdom arise from wisdom;
non-wisdom does not arise from non-wisdom, nor does wisdom arise from wisdom;
wisdom is not called wisdom due to non-wisdom, nor is wisdom called non-wisdom due to wisdom;
It is not because of non-wisdom that it is called non-wisdom, nor is it because of wisdom that it is called wisdom.
Rather, it is precisely because of non-wisdom that it is called wisdom, and it is precisely because of wisdom that it is called non-wisdom.

Here, wisdom cannot be demonstrated as this is called wisdom, it cannot be demonstrated that this wisdom belongs to something, it cannot be demonstrated that this wisdom is due to something, it cannot be demonstrated that this wisdom comes from something. Therefore, within wisdom there is no real nature of wisdom, and there is also no real wisdom abiding in the nature of wisdom. Wisdom and the nature of wisdom are both unobtainable.

Non-wisdom and its nature are also like this. It is definitely not because of non-wisdom that it is called wisdom. If it is said that wisdom is called wisdom because of non-wisdom, then all foolish people should have wisdom.
If there is someone who, as it is, does not obtain either wisdom or non-wisdom, and who, as it is, thoroughly knows wisdom and non-wisdom, this is called wisdom.
However, the true nature of wisdom is not as it is said.
Why is this?
Because the true nature of wisdom is apart from words and speech.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The realm of wisdom is neither the realm of wisdom nor the realm of non-wisdom, because wisdom transcends all realms and cannot be said to be the realm of wisdom or non-wisdom.
Good son!
This is called the true explanation of the characteristics of wisdom.
Such characteristics of wisdom cannot truly be explained or demonstrated, but are explained and shown in accordance with the understanding of sentient beings;
Those who are able to know it also cannot be said to exist, for the realm of wisdom does not even exist, let alone a wise one!
If one is able to understand this as it truly is and to awaken to it as it truly is, this is called prajÃ±Ä.

If one is able to realize this as it truly is, this is called supramundane prajÃ±Ä. Such supramundane prajÃ±Ä as is explained cannot be said to exist.
Why is this?
The world itself does not exist, let alone anything supramundane!
That which is to be emerged from does not even exist, let alone that which is able to emerge!
Therefore, supramundane prajÃ±Ä also does not exist.
Why is this?

Because nothing whatsoever is found in the world or beyond the world that can transcend or be transcended, it can be said to be supramundane wisdom. If there were something to be attained, it would not be called supramundane wisdom.
The nature of this wisdom is also unobtainable, because it is free from the nature of attainability such as existence and non-existence.
Moreover, O Virtuous One!

The world is provisionally established, and there is no real world to transcend in provisional establishment. However, because it transcends all provisional [names and forms], it is called supramundane. Moreover, the supramundane is neither truly in the world nor does it transcend the world.
Why is it so?
Because in this [supramundane wisdom], there is not even the slightest dharma that can be transcended or that can transcend, it is called supramundane.
Moreover, the supramundane is neither the world nor beyond the world, neither transcendence nor non-transcendence, and therefore it is called supramundane.
If one can understand this as it truly is, this is called supramundane wisdom.
This kind of wisdom is not as it is described.
Why is it so?
Because supramundane prajÃ±Ä transcends all verbal paths.

Although it is called supramundane, it has nothing to transcend. Although it is called prajÃ±Ä, it has nothing to know, because what is transcended and what is known cannot be obtained. That which can transcend and that which can know are also unobtainable. Knowing this as it really is is called supramundane prajÃ±Ä.
Because of this prajÃ±Ä, there is nothing that is not transcended. Therefore, it is called supramundane prajÃ±Ä.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
This is also called penetrating prajÃ±Ä.
What does this prajÃ±Ä penetrate?
This prajÃ±Ä penetrates nothing.

If this prajÃ±Ä penetrated something, it would be a provisional designation. If it were a provisional designation, it would not be called penetrating prajÃ±Ä. It is said that in this there is absolutely nothing, neither this nor that, nor anything in between. There is no one who penetrates, nothing that is penetrated, no place of penetration, no time of penetration, and no one who penetrates. Therefore, it is called penetration;
Moreover, in this there is absolutely nothing, no one who practices, no place to practice, no this, no that, and also no middle, and therefore it is called penetrating insight.

Moreover, penetrating insight is called penetration, but this penetrating insight is absolutely nothing, with nothing above or below, nothing slow or fast, nothing advancing or retreating, nothing going or coming, and therefore it is called penetration.
Moreover, O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
What does penetrating insight penetrate?
It is that which sees and penetrates everything.
By what does it penetrate?
It is by prajÃ±Ä.
How does such prajÃ±Ä penetrate?
It is by means of the characteristics of designation that there is penetration.
All the characteristics of designation are not characteristics, and such non-characteristics are called the characteristics of designation.
Moreover, O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!ğŸ”½Those who accomplish such prajÃ±Ä are able to penetrate the three realms as they truly are.
How does one penetrate the three realms as they truly are?
It means that which is not the three realms is called the three realms.
Why is it so?
Herein there is no realm that can be penetrated, penetrating the three realms is itself not a realm.
By being able to penetrate the three realms in this way, it is called accomplishing the penetration of prajÃ±Ä.
What is meant by accomplishing the penetration of prajÃ±Ä?
It means that there is nothing that is not well penetrated, all things are well penetrated, therefore it is called the penetration of prajÃ±Ä, such prajÃ±Ä transcends all things.
If one accomplishes such prajÃ±Ä, all that is seen, heard, smelled, tasted, and cognized is well penetrated.
What is meant by penetration?

It means impermanence, suffering, a boil, a disease, an arrow, emptiness, obstruction, harm, other, destruction, the nature of destruction, movement, rapid cessation, no-self, no arising, no cessation, no characteristics, and so forth.
SubhÅ«ti!
If one can penetrate this, it is called 'cool and free from arrows.'
There is a good medicine called 'free from arrows,' which wherever it is applied, all arrows are removed, and poisonous medicine cannot remain there, because the power of this medicine forces it out.

In the same way, if there are bhiká¹£us who accomplish this Dharma, which is cool and free from arrows, namely, accomplishing the penetration of prajÃ±Ä, endowed with the six constant abodes, penetrating prajÃ±Ä, far removed from all defilements of the three realms, transcending all evil mÄras' nets.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!
It is like a diamond drill, which wherever it drills, it penetrates through.
In the same way, if there are bhiká¹£us whose diamond-like samÄdhi is embraced by penetrating wisdom, then wherever they observe dharmas, they penetrate through;
this penetrating wisdom is embraced by the diamond-like samÄdhi, and wherever they observe dharmas, they penetrate through.

If one attains this penetrating wisdom, one can transcend the world and completely end all suffering, heading towards the end of all suffering without attachment. This penetrating wisdom is also called the three kinds of clear knowledge.
Good son!

What is meant by clear knowledge is the complete cessation of ignorance, which is also called the thorough understanding of ignorance, and is also called the ability to end the aggregates of suffering.

It is like a skilled doctor who is intelligent and knowledgeable, who observes well whatever he does, and who, because of his accomplishment in subtle wisdom through observation, is well-versed in medicines, well-versed in the causes of illnesses, well-versed in the characteristics of illnesses, and able to save people from suffering, curing all illnesses without exception.
Why is this?
Because he is well-versed in the combination of medicines, illnesses, causes, and characteristics, he is able to cure all illnesses and suffering.

In the same way, if one attains the third illumination, one can extinguish all ignorance, can quell all suffering, can eliminate all birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress, and this is called supramundane penetrating insight.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
I speak these words with this meaning in mind:
All worldly wisdom is supreme, namely, that which penetrates the true nature of dharmas, and by this right knowledge brings an end to birth.
What is the term for the end of birth?
It is the term for penetrating emergence and submergence.
What is meant by penetrating emergence and submergence?
It means skillfully penetrating that all dharmas that arise have the characteristic of cessation, and this is called penetrating emergence and submergence.
SubhÅ«ti!
Emergence is a term for birth, and submergence is a term for cessation, although it is said thus, it is not as it is said that there is emergence and submergence.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!
All that is accumulated is not a truly emerging dharma.
Why is it so?
Good son!
The accumulation is said to be the emergence of equality, not the emergence of inequality, and also not the submergence of existence, because it arises in accordance with equality.
Arising in accordance with equality means that there is neither emergence nor submergence in this.
Such a self-nature naturally decays, which is then called cessation. There is nothing called cessation in this, namely the cessation without interval;
It is not that what arises here ceases here, which is called cessation;
It is precisely because there is no arising that it is called cessation.
Thus, penetrating through emergence and submergence as being without arising and without cessation is called penetrating through emergence and submergence.
Furthermore, Good Son!ğŸ”½What is called penetration is the thorough understanding of dependent origination.
Because all dharmas arise due to conditions, it is called dependent origination.

Thus dependent arising is utterly nonexistent. This is called penetrating dependent arising, and this is called thoroughly knowing dependent arising. It is said that it reveals reality as it is, without arising.

Because there is no arising, it is called dependent arising. Because there is no arising in equality, it is called dependent arising. That is to say, arising does not even exist in this place, let alone cessation.

Following the realization of dependent arising, both conformity and nonconformity cannot be obtained, because there is no arising. Because there is no arising, there is no birth. If there is no birth, there is no past and also no already arisen. If there is no past and also no already arisen, there is no cessation. If there is no cessation, then there is no knowledge of birth. Due to the knowledge of non-birth, one does not give rise to anything again, and also does not realize cessation.
Because there is no birth, there is also no cessation. Because there is birth, cessation is established. Since there is no birth, therefore there is no cessation.
Knowing and seeing all dharmas in this way, penetrating and realizing them, is called the knowledge of termination.
Well-skilled in means!
The knowledge of termination is so called because it terminates nescience.
By what is it called terminated?
It is called terminated because of non-termination. No dharma is seen that can be called terminated.
However, it is called the knowledge of termination because it is free from nescience, and it is called the knowledge of termination because it terminates nescience.
Because it thoroughly knows all dharmas of nescience, it is called the termination of nescience. Because it terminates nescience, it is called the knowledge of termination.
Dharmas of nescience are neither terminated nor not terminated. However, it is called the knowledge of termination because it is free from nescience.

Because it thoroughly knows that these dharmas of nescience are utterly nonexistent, it is called freedom. Because of such knowledge, it knows that dharmas of nescience are not separately obtained, and it is called the freedom from nescience.
However, dharmas of nescience are truly unobtainable. Knowledge itself does not exist, let alone nescience!
If one can be liberated from termination, it is called the knowledge of termination.

Although it is said like this, it is not as said. All the knowledge of extinction is completely indescribable, but it is provisionally called the knowledge of extinction, and also called the knowledge of extinction.

If one observes all dharmas with this inexhaustible knowledge of extinction, the knowledge of extinction also does not exist. If one knows in this way, one departs from the knowledge of extinction and reaches the inexhaustible end. This inexhaustible end is the end of non-end, and also the end of nirvana;
Although it is said like this, it is not as said. Because all dharmas are the end of non-end, and also the end of nirvana. The permanent severance of all ends is called the end of nirvana;
Although it is said like this, it is not as said. Because the end of nirvana is permanently free from verbal expression. All verbal expressions are permanently extinguished within it.
Moreover, O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!

Although the TathÄgata speaks of the realm of nirvana, it is not as said. Because the realm of nirvana is completely indescribable, transcending all expressions. In the realm of nirvana, all expressions are permanently severed.
If the characteristics of the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a are explained in this way, it is called explaining the characteristics of supramundane penetrating prajÃ±Ä.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!
The realm of nirvÄá¹‡a cannot be said to be located here or there. Therefore, nirvÄá¹‡a is truly inexpressible.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
What is meant by the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ here?
SubhÅ«ti!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ has no distant shore that can be attained.
SubhÅ«ti!
If this prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ had a distant shore that could be attained, the TathÄgata would have to explain that this profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ has a distant shore.
SubhÅ«ti!
This prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ has no distance that can be attained, and therefore it is not said to have a shore beyond.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!

This is called prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, which means the wisdom that accomplishes the ultimate perfection of all dharmas, and is therefore called prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ. Although it is said in this way, it is not as it is said.
Why is this?
Neither speech nor action can reach prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Why is this?
Good and courageous one!
Because the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ cannot be spoken of.
Moreover, good and courageous one!
The profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ accords with the realization of dharmas. If one can accord with realization, then one goes against realization.
Why is this?

Herein there is nothing that can be called accord with realization. Because of the non-existence of accord with realization, realization also does not exist. It is the meaning of non-penetration with regard to all dharmas.
Because the equality of the nature of dharmas that is realized through accord with realization is bodhi, accord with realization is called bodhi.
How is it able to accord with the realization of dharmas?
There is nothing here that can be called enlightenment, so there is also no subsequent realization here.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
If there were any part of enlightenment that could be attained, then enlightenment should be attained within enlightenment;

But enlightenment does not exist within enlightenment. One should realize enlightenment in this way. Because it is not subsequent realization, and because it is not thorough understanding, it is called enlightenment.

Although it is said like this, it is not as it is said. Because all dharmas cannot be subsequently realized, cannot be thoroughly understood, and because both dharmas and non-dharmas are devoid of intrinsic nature, the realization of this principle is called enlightenment.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!ğŸ”½It is not the TathÄgatas, Arhats, Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas who can attain enlightenment;
It is not the TathÄgatas, Arhats, Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas who can understand enlightenment, because true enlightenment cannot be understood, cannot be expressed;
It is not that the TathÄgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Enlightened Ones give rise to enlightenment, because enlightenment has the nature of being unborn and unarisen.
Moreover, SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
It is said that enlightenment belongs to no one, and within enlightenment there are no sentient beings or designations of sentient beings.

Since within enlightenment there are no sentient beings or designations of sentient beings, how can it be said that this is the enlightenment of sentient beings, and this is the perfection of wisdom of the bodhisattva of enlightenment?
Moreover, SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
Enlightenment cannot be attained within enlightenment, and sentient beings cannot be attained within enlightenment.
Why is it so?
SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!

Bodhi transcends, bodhi is unborn, bodhi is unarisen, bodhi is signless. Within bodhi there is no sattva nature, within bodhi a sattva cannot be found, bodhi is not established by means of a sattva, a sattva is not established by means of bodhi. Because the self-nature of a sattva is not realized, it is called bodhi.
Knowing that in reality there is no sattva within bodhi, therefore it is called bodhisattva.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
Bodhisattva is not revealed by the thought of sattva. In order to eliminate the thought of sattva, it is called bodhisattva. Although it is said like this, it is not as it is said.
Why is it so?
Because bodhisattva is apart from words.
Bodhisattva is apart from the nature of sattva, bodhisattva is apart from the thought of sattva, because of knowing bodhi it is called bodhisattva.
How can a bodhisattva know bodhi?

It is said that bodhi transcends everything. Bodhi is non-action, non-arising, and non-cessation. The nature of bodhi cannot understand bodhi, and bodhi is not what is illuminated. It cannot be illuminated, cannot be established, and cannot be turned away from, and is therefore called bodhi.

If one can understand and penetrate without error, without discrimination, with discrimination permanently severed, it is therefore called a bodhisattva. Although it is said in this way, it is not as it is said.
Why is it so?
Good and courageous one!
Because a bodhisattva cannot be attained.
If there were a bodhisattva to be attained, then one could attain this is bodhi, this belongs to bodhi, this is a bodhisattva, this belongs to a bodhisattva;

However, it cannot be said that this is enlightenment or belongs to enlightenment, nor can it be said that this is a sentient being or belongs to a sentient being. Because it can awaken to the fact that there truly are no sentient beings, and the nature of sentient beings is non-existent and apart from the nature of sentient beings, it is called a bodhisattva. Because it removes the notion of sentient beings by being without sentient beings, it is called a bodhisattva.
Why is it so?
Virtuous One!

The realm of sentient beings is a term for the non-existence of real sentient beings. There is no nature of sentient beings among sentient beings, and because sentient beings do not exist, it is called the realm of sentient beings;
If there were a nature of sentient beings among sentient beings, then it should not be called the realm of sentient beings.

The realm of sentient beings indicates the absence of a realm, because the realm of sentient beings has no nature of a realm.ğŸ”½If the realm of sentient beings were to exist as the nature of a realm, then there should truly be a life-possessor that is the same as the body;
If the realm of sentient beings were to exist apart from the nature of a realm, then there should truly be a life-possessor that is different from the body;
However, the realm of sentient beings has no real nature of realms, but is only provisionally called realms by worldly convention.
Within the realm of sentient beings, there cannot be the nature of realms, nor can there be the realm of sentient beings within the nature of realms;
The nature of realms is not the realm of sentient beings, and apart from the nature of realms there are no sentient beings. Because all dharmas have no nature of realms.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
I speak this meaning in a hidden way, saying:
The realm of sentient beings cannot be said to have decrease or fullness.
Why is it so?
Because the realm of sentient beings is not an existent nature, and the realm of sentient beings is apart from an existent nature.

Just as the realm of sentient beings cannot be said to have decrease or fullness, all dharmas are also like this, and cannot be said to have decrease or fullness. Because all dharmas are all without real nature, it cannot be said that they have decrease or fullness;
If one is able to thus follow the realization of all dharmas, this is then called following the realization of the Buddha Dharma.
I rely on this meaning to speak in secret:
Just as the realm of sentient beings cannot be said to have decrease or fullness, so it is with all dharmas, which cannot be said to have decrease or fullness;
If all dharmas have no decrease and no fullness, then using non-reality as a skillful means is precisely the Buddha Dharma having no decrease and no fullness.

In this way, because one accords with the realization of all dharmas, it is called the Buddha Dharma having no decrease and no fullness. Because all dharmas have no decrease and no fullness, it is called the Buddha Dharma.
The Buddha Dharma is a term that does not increase or decrease the Buddha Dharma. There is no entity of the Buddha Dharma that can cause it to decrease or to be full.
Why is it so?
Because it accords with the realization of all dharmas. If one can accord with the realization of the nature of all dharmas, then there is no dharma here that decreases or is full.
One should know that all dharmas are a term for the dharma realm. The dharma realm has no decrease and no fullness.
Why is it so?
Because the dharma realm has no boundary.

The realms of sentient beings and phenomena are not to be found, and the realms of sentient beings and phenomena are neither diminished nor fulfilled, neither attained nor existent. Such realization is called bodhi.
For this reason it is said:
The dharmas of the buddhas cannot be established as diminished or fulfilled.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!

If the nature of non-diminishment and non-fulfillment can be truly and non-conceptually realized, it should be known as the realization of reality. There is neither acceptance nor rejection in this. Such realization is called bodhi.
SubhÅ«ti!
Bodhi is the characteristic of a buddha. What are the characteristics of a buddha?
It is the characteristic of all characteristics being ultimately without characteristics, which is the characteristic of a buddha.
Why is this?
SubhÅ«ti!
The ultimately characteristicless and the characteristic of bodhi are inherently separated.
Such realization is called bodhi, although it is expressed in this way, it is not as it is expressed.
Why is this?
SubhÅ«ti!
Because they are able to awaken to such dharmas, they are called bodhisattvas.
If there are bodhisattvas who do not truly understand such dharma-nature, and yet claim:
'I am able to awaken to it as it truly is,'

and proclaim themselves bodhisattvas, you should know that such people are far from the stage of bodhisattvas, far from the dharmas of bodhisattvas, and they deceive devas, humans, asuras, and others with the name of bodhisattvas.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!
If one merely makes empty claims and proclaims oneself a bodhisattva to become a bodhisattva, then all sentient beings should be bodhisattvas.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
It is not by empty words alone that one enters the stage of bodhisattvas, attains the dharmas of bodhisattvas, or by the power of speech;

one is able to realize unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, nor is it by the power of speech that one attains enlightenment by proclaiming one's name, nor is it by the power of speech that one enters the stage of bodhisattvas and attains the dharmas of bodhisattvas by proclaiming one's name.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!
All sentient beings who practice the bodhisattva path, but do not know or realize the true nature of phenomena, are not called bodhisattvas.
Why is this?
Because they do not know that sentient beings are not sentient beings.
If they knew the nature of sentient beings is not sentient beings, then practicing the bodhisattva path would be considered practicing as a bodhisattva;

However, due to delusion, sentient beings are unable to realize their own conduct, their own objects, and their own sphere of activity. If they truly understood their own conduct, they would no longer engage in conceptualized conduct;
Due to conceptualized conduct, all foolish beings give rise to inverted conduct based on false objects, and also give rise to conceit and grasping in relation to enlightenment.

Because they give rise to inverted conduct based on false objects, and conduct characterized by conceptualization, they are unable to attain even the qualities of bodhisattvas, let alone enlightenment!

If one is able to understand such dharmas, then one will no longer give rise to conduct based on falsehood, and will also no longer give rise to conceit in relation to dharmas. This is called the bodhisattva practicing without practice.
Bodhisattvas should not give rise to conceptual practices due to conceptualization. If there is no conceptualization in a certain place, there is no practice in that place;
if there is no arising of conceptualization in a certain place, there is no practice in that place either.
Because the buddhas and bodhisattvas practice without conceptualizing any practices, all arrogance and conceit do not arise.

Bodhisattvas who know all dharmas in this way no longer grasp at any dharmas, no longer conceptualize, no longer wander, and no longer tread. This is called the true practice of bodhisattvas, because non-action is the skillful means.
If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, this is called the true practice of bodhisattvas.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
Because being able to thus realize and penetrate all dharmas is called a bodhisattva.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
No sentient beings should be known as a synonym for bodhisattvas, because they are able to eliminate all conceptual thoughts.
Why is this?

Because they are able to understand that all sentient beings are not truly sentient beings, all sentient beings are not sentient beings, all sentient beings are sentient beings who are inverted and attached, all sentient beings are sentient beings who are imagined, all sentient beings are sentient beings who are falsely cognized, all sentient beings are sentient beings who act in a ruinous way, and all sentient beings are sentient beings whose actions are conditioned by ignorance.
Why is this?
Good son!
If a dharma and all sentient beings are not created by any kind of sentient beings, this is called sentient beings whose actions are conditioned by ignorance.
What dharma does not exist?
It refers to the self that is grasped, the mine that is grasped, the grasping of self and mine, and the reliance on what is grasped. That dharma does not exist.

If there were such a dharma, all sentient beings would grasp it as the self and grasp it as what belongs to the self. What is grasped by the grasping of the self and what belongs to the self, and what is relied upon, should all truly exist and not be called false.

Because there is no such dharma, sentient beings mistakenly grasp it as the self and grasp it as what belongs to the self. What is grasped by the grasping of the self and what belongs to the self, and what is relied upon, all do not truly exist and are all false. Therefore, it is said:
All sentient beings are not truly sentient beings. All sentient beings are sentient beings conditioned by the ignorance of karmic formations.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!

There is no name of sentient being that has even a little real dharma that can be grasped as the self, or as what belongs to the self, or as what is grasped by the two graspings, or as what is relied upon;
Because there is no real dharma, therefore it can be said that all sentient beings are not truly sentient beings.ğŸ”½Those who are not sentient beings should be known as the non-real superimposition;
Those who are not real should be known as the non-sentient being superimposition.
It is also like the case where, in the thought of non-real sentient beings, all sentient beings mistakenly grasp as real, and therefore it is said:
All sentient beings are not real sentient beings.
Moreover, O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
As for the non-real, it means that in this [thought] there is no reality and no arising, because all dharmas are without true reality and also without arising.
Herein, sentient beings falsely grasp and cling to themselves, and therefore it can be said that all sentient beings are sentient beings with false objects.
They are unable to understand their own actions, and therefore it can be said that non-real sentient beings are precisely the meaning of non-universal awakening in this [thought].
If there is universal awakening to all conditioned things, one should know that such a type can be called a bodhisattva.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The Great PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra, Scroll 593, Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order, Part 16, Chapter on PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ, Section 2 Furthermore, O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to awaken to and understand the Dharma in this way, they can be called true bodhisattvas.
As for the term 'bodhisattva,' it refers to being able to awaken to the fact that sentient beings are unreal and unborn.
Moreover, a bodhisattva is also able to know all dharmas as they are, just as the Buddha does.
How is it that a bodhisattva knows as the Buddha does?
It means knowing that the nature of all dharmas is unreal, unborn, and also not false.

Moreover, the nature of all dharmas is not as grasped at by foolish ordinary beings, and is not attained by foolish ordinary beings. Because [bodhisattvas] know it as it is, it is called 'bodhisattva.'
Why is it so?
Good and Brave One!
The so-called enlightenment is because there is no attachment, no discrimination, no accumulation, and no attainment.
Moreover, Good and Brave One!

It is not that the TathÄgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Enlightened Ones have attained anything in the nature of enlightenment, because all dharmas are unattainable. The absence of attainment in regard to dharmas is called enlightenment.
The enlightenment of the Buddhas should be taught in this way, but it is not taught in this way, because it is free from all characteristics.
Moreover, O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
If bodhisattvas arouse the mind of enlightenment, thinking like this:
'I now arouse the mind of enlightenment.
This is enlightenment. I now arouse the mind of practice in order to attain this enlightenment.'
Because these bodhisattvas have something to attain, they cannot be called bodhisattvas, but can only be called deluded sattvas.
Why is it so?
O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
Because those bodhisattvas definitely grasp at the nature of arousal, definitely grasp at the mind of enlightenment, and definitely grasp at the nature of enlightenment.

If bodhisattvas give rise to the mind of enlightenment while still attached, they can only be called those with attachment to the mind of enlightenment, not true and pure bodhisattvas who have given rise to the mind of enlightenment.ğŸ”½Because they give rise to the mind of enlightenment through fabrication, they are therefore called those with fabricated minds, not bodhisattvas;
Because they give rise to the mind of enlightenment through application, they are therefore called those with applied minds, not bodhisattvas.
Why is this?
Good son!
Because those bodhisattvas give rise to the mind of enlightenment while still grasping, they can only be called those who have given rise to the mind of enlightenment, not bodhisattvas.
Moreover, good son!
There is no one who truly gives rise to the mind of enlightenment, because the mind of enlightenment cannot be given rise to, because enlightenment is unborn and also has no mind.
Those bodhisattvas only grasp at giving rise to the mind of enlightenment, but do not understand the meaning of the unborn mind of enlightenment.
Moreover, good son!
If the nature of equality is the true nature of equality, and if the true nature of equality is the nature of equality of mind, then the nature of equality of mind is precisely enlightenment.
If there is suchness in this, then there is no discrimination in this.

If there is a discriminating mind and enlightenment, then one will be attached to mind and enlightenment. Because of these two, one should know that the mind that gives rise to enlightenment is not called the true mind that gives rise to enlightenment.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!

Enlightenment and mind are not each different, there is no real enlightenment within the mind, and real mind cannot be obtained within enlightenment. Enlightenment and mind are both indescribable as enlightenment or mind in accordance with reality and principle.

Because of the realization of suchness, enlightenment and mind are both unobtainable, unborn and not born, and therefore called bodhisattvas, also called mahÄsattvas and beings in accordance with reality.
Why is it so?
Because one truly knows the nature that is not real.
How does one truly know what is not truly existent?
It means that all worlds are not truly existent, are not included in reality, and do not truly arise, but are only provisionally established.
How is it that worlds do not truly arise, but are only provisionally established?
That which is not truly existent has no true arising.
Because there is no true arising and because they are not truly existent, it is said that all dharmas are without true existence and without nature.
Because one truly knows what is not truly existent, one can also be said to truly know sentient beings;
Because one does not grasp at true existence even within true existence, one can also be said to accord with truly existent sentient beings.
Although this is said, it is not as it is said.
Why is it so?
There are no sentient beings or mahÄsattvas in the true principle. Why is it so?
Good and courageous one!
Because entering the Great Vehicle is called being a mahÄsattva.
Furthermore, good and courageous one!
What is called the Great Vehicle?
It means all-knowledge is called the Great Vehicle.
What is omniscience?

It refers to all knowledge, whether knowledge of conditioned phenomena, knowledge of unconditioned phenomena, worldly knowledge, or supramundane knowledge. One who is able to realize and enter such knowledge is called a mahÄsattva.
Why is this so?

translated: Because they are able to distance themselves from the great conception of sentient beings, they are called mahÄsattvas. Because they are able to distance themselves from the great mass of ignorance, they are called mahÄsattvas. Because they are able to distance themselves from the great mass of various activities, they are called mahÄsattvas. Because they are able to distance themselves from the great mass of unknowing, they are called mahÄsattvas. Because they are able to distance themselves from the great mass of various sufferings, they are called mahÄsattvas.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!
If they are able to distance themselves from the great conception of sentient beings, they are called mahÄsattvas.
Although they do not attain anything regarding the mind and mental factors, they are able to understand the fundamental nature of the mind.
Although they do not attain anything regarding enlightenment and the factors of enlightenment, they are able to understand the fundamental nature of enlightenment.

By this wisdom, they do not see enlightenment within the mind, nor do they see enlightenment apart from the mind. They do not see a real mind within enlightenment, nor do they see a real mind apart from enlightenment.

Thus, they abandon what is to be cultivated and what is to be abandoned, and with regard to what is to be cultivated and what is to be abandoned, they have no attainment, no reliance, and no attachment. Although they do not see the nature of the enlightened mind, they are able to give rise to the mind of great enlightenment.
If one is able to give rise to the mind of enlightenment in this way, then one may be called a true bodhisattva.
Although they give rise to the mind of enlightenment in this way, they do not give rise to anything with regard to enlightenment.
Why is it so?
O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
Because they have already attained great enlightenment.

If one can be like this, without attachment, not seeing at all the arising, ceasing, or distinctions of mind and enlightenment, and also not seeing one who gives rise to the mind and heads towards great enlightenment, without seeing, without grasping, without discrimination, one should know that one has already abided in unsurpassed enlightenment.
If one can be like this, without attachment, giving rise to the mind of superior understanding and liberation, one should be known as a true bodhisattva.
Moreover, O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
If bodhisattvas do not give rise to the mind of enlightenment apart from the thought of mind and the thought of enlightenment, they are far from enlightenment, not near to enlightenment.
Moreover, O SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
If bodhisattvas do not see enlightenment as either far or near, one should know that they are near to unsurpassed enlightenment, and are also called true givers rise to the mind of enlightenment.
I rely on this meaning and speak with an underlying intent, saying:
If one can know for oneself the characteristic of non-duality, then one truly knows all the Buddha-Dharmas.
Why is it so?

They are able to realize and understand that both the self and sentient beings are devoid of intrinsic nature, and thus they are able to thoroughly know the non-duality of all phenomena. Because they are able to thoroughly know the non-duality of all phenomena, they are certainly able to understand that the self, sentient beings, and all phenomena are all devoid of intrinsic nature, and the principle is no different.
If one is able to understand the non-duality of all phenomena, one is able to understand all the Buddha's teachings;
if one is able to thoroughly know the non-duality of all phenomena, one is able to thoroughly know all the Buddha's teachings.
If one is able to thoroughly know the self, one thoroughly knows the three realms.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!
If one thoroughly knows the self, one will then be able to reach the other shore of all phenomena.
What is called the other shore of all phenomena?
It refers to the true nature of the equality of all phenomena.

If one does not attain this and does not grasp at this, if one does not reach the other shore and does not grasp at the other shore, that person is called one who thoroughly knows and reaches the other shore, although it is said like this, it is not as it is said.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!

The assembly of bodhisattvas should thus enter the stages of the bodhisattvas, and should thus realize the stages of the bodhisattvas. One should know that this is precisely the prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ of the bodhisattvas, namely, that in this there is not a single dharma that can be entered or realized, because in this there is no establishment of coming and going.
At that time, SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
Those who are arrogant and practice with characteristics should not be afraid of what the Buddha has said.
Then ÅšÄriputra said to SubhÅ«ti:
The realm of those who are not arrogant and practice with characteristics, what is there to be afraid of?
Why is it so?
Those who are afraid are apart from arrogance, are embraced by evil friends, and when hearing the profound Dharma are unable to fathom it. Fearing the loss of what they seek, they give rise to fear.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
Those who wish to eliminate conceit and practice correctly may have fear, and those who wish to eliminate conceit and make energetic progress may also have fear.
Why is this?

Because they are able to understand the loss of conceit, seek the absence of conceit, and seek to eliminate conceit. Hearing the profound Dharma, they are unable to fathom it, fearing the loss of what they seek, they give rise to fear.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!
If one does not see conceit as something to be grasped, has no reliance, and no attachment, then one will have no fear or terror regarding all dharmas.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!
The TathÄgata does not teach such a Dharma for those with conceit, therefore they have no room for fear in this.
Those who wish to eliminate conceit and diligently practice will, upon hearing such a Dharma, be able to understand it correctly and will also have no fear.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!

The name superior conceit should be known to show the superior dharma that is added. If there is one who presently engages in superior conceit, they will certainly presently engage in the superior dharma that is added, because engaging in addition is not the same as engaging in equality.
If they set up the practice of equality, then in this profound dharma their minds will be full of doubt, and they will not give rise to fear or believe and accept it.
Moreover, rejoice!

If in equality and inequality one has nothing to attain, if in equality and inequality one has nothing to rely on, if in equality and inequality one has nothing to grasp, then one will not be startled, frightened, terrified, or afraid of all dharmas.
Moreover, rejoice!

This profound Dharma is not the domain of foolish ordinary beings, it is not the realm of foolish ordinary beings, it is not understood by foolish ordinary beings, because it transcends all that is practiced, embraced, and realized by foolish ordinary beings.
Those who are inclined towards the vehicle of the hearers, although they practice the profound Dharma, this profound Dharma is not what they practice.
Those who are inclined towards the vehicle of the solitary realizers, although they practice the profound Dharma, this profound Dharma is not what they practice.

Those who are inclined towards the vehicle of the bodhisattvas, if they practice with characteristics, are far from good friends, and are embraced by bad friends, they also cannot practice this Dharma of non-attachment, because it is not their realm.
Ä€nanda should know!

Except for those who have seen the truth, seek great enlightenment, and are included among the Å›rÄvaka vehicle and so forth, and those who are embraced by the good friends of the bodhisattva vehicle, who are able to give rise to faith and understanding in this profound Dharma, who are able to practice in accordance with this profound Dharma, and who are able to deeply realize and unite with this profound Dharma.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!

If bodhisattvas are far removed from various characteristics, abide in the absence of characteristics, practice without distinctions, in the profound Dharma ultimately transcend various doubts, nets, discriminations, and attachments, are able to accomplish whatever they wish, do not attain anything in mind or enlightenment, have non-discriminating understanding of the nature of all dharmas, and also do not give rise to discriminatory practices, then wherever they go they are able to realize and enter.
They are able to uphold such profound Dharma gates without any doubts in their minds.
Why is it so?

They all abide in accordance with the dharmas, without any opposition. If there are any questions about the dharmas, they are all able to answer in accordance with them, reconciling them so that they are not contradictory.
The Buddha speaks this profound Dharma for their sake.
At that time, the Buddha told the Venerable Ananda:
You should uphold what Shariputra has said. His explanation is no different from mine.
Ananda, you should know!
Those with excessive pride cannot understand this Dharma teaching, because it is not their realm, not their level.
Ananda, you should know!
Such a Dharma teaching accords with the nature of all dharmas, accords with the Buddha's enlightenment, and can assist in the Buddha's enlightenment.
Beings with inferior faith and understanding will not be enlightened to this profound and vast Buddha Dharma, and will not be able to accept and practice it.
Ananda, you should know!

Those of inferior faith and understanding, who are arrogant, will go against and dwell in opposition to the Buddha's enlightenment and the profound Dharma. Whatever they do will be in accordance with their arrogance, and they will be unable to believe and accept this profound Dharma.
Ä€nanda should know!

This present assembly is the most excellent and pure, far removed from defilement. They have made vast vows in the presence of many Buddhas, planted immeasurable and excellent roots of goodness, served limitless past Buddhas, and have long given rise to faith and understanding in the profound Dharma, and have already matured in the practice of profound conduct.

Therefore, the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, trusts this assembly without suspicion. The Dharma gates he speaks are all clear and distinct, and he expounds the essential Dharma without holding anything back.
Ä€nanda should know!

This present assembly is firm and pure, without any impurities like gravel or salt. They have already made offerings to many hundreds of thousands of Buddhas and are firmly established in the Buddhadharma.
Ä€nanda should know!ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The phrase like tiles and pebbles is an expression for foolish ordinary beings, meaning they are incapable of receiving the profound Dharma.
The phrase salty and bitter should be understood as an expression for those with excessive pride, meaning they are unable to give rise to profound practices.
Ä€nanda should know!
This present assembly is free from excessive pride, and has been brought together by vast roots of goodness, being vessels for the profound Dharma.
Furthermore, Ä€nanda!

It is like the great nÄga king Anavatapta, who for some reason gives rise to great joy, and in his own palace enjoys the five desires and pleasures. Out of joy, he again causes a great rain endowed with eight qualities to fall in his own palace.
Then, the various sons each go to their own palaces and also enjoy the five desires and pleasures, harmoniously playing and causing a great sweet rain to fall.
In this way, the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, causes a great rain of the Dharma to fall for the various assemblies.

At that time, the assembly of innumerable great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having heard this, either in this SahÄ world, facing their own TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, rained down the great Dharma rain for the assembly, or went to their own buddha lands, facing the TathÄgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Enlightened Ones, each raining down the great Dharma rain for their own assembly.
Furthermore, Ä€nanda!
Just as when the dragon king of the ocean is sometimes delighted, he rains down a great rain in his own palace.
The old dragons dwelling in the palace, following the rain, all joyfully accept it, well knowing the extent of this great rain.
Those dragon sons are also each delighted, able to accept the great rain that the father king has rained down.
Why is this?
There are other dragons who do not know the extent of the rain that has been rained down, and are also unable to joyfully accept it.
In the same way, the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, in the great assembly, rains down the profound Dharma treasures.

There are the Buddha's eldest sons, the great bodhisattvas, who have long planted immeasurable superior wholesome roots, who have been nurtured by the profound Dharma doors, who have accomplished various vast aspirations, and who are able to receive the TathÄgata's great Dharma rain. Having heard it, they rejoice and well know the limits.
For this meaning, now in the TathÄgata's pure assembly, the Great Teacher roars the lion's roar, rains down the great Dharma rain, and brings great benefit.
Furthermore, Ä€nanda!
Like a wheel-turning king who has many sons, whose maternal lineage is pure and whose appearance is dignified.
Sometimes the king gathers many treasures and commands his sons to distribute them, his mind is completely free from deception and partiality.
Then, the princes, having obtained many treasures, give rise to even deeper respect and love for their father, each thinking:
'We now truly know that our father king shares benefits with us.

In the same way, the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the Great Dharma Lord, the Great Dharma King, naturally gathers the true sons of the Buddhas and distributes to them the great Dharma treasury, with a mind that is completely free from deception and partiality.
Then, the Buddha's disciples, having obtained the wonderful Dharma, give rise to respect and love for the TathÄgata even more deeply, each thinking like this:
We now truly know that the TathÄgata shares the same benefits with us. We should now diligently make progress, continuing and upholding the Buddha's lineage, so that it is not cut off.
Moreover, Ä€nanda!
This Dharma treasure is subtle and profound, and other sentient beings are unable to believe in and accept it.

Those of inferior faith and understanding, those with excessive pride, those who practice evil views, those who practice with characteristics, those who practice with attainments, those who are destroyed by the arrogance of self-importance, those who are overwhelmed by greed, anger, and delusion, those who practice outside the pathâ€”such people are called other sentient beings, and they are unable to believe in and accept this Dharma door.
SubhÅ«ti should know!

Inferior sentient beings with inferior faith and understanding cannot respect and love the wealth of the wheel-turning king, but only the wheel-turning king's princes can give rise to respect and love.
SubhÅ«ti should know!

How could poor and inferior sentient beings covet the wheel-turning king's precious wheel, precious elephant, precious horse, precious jewel, precious woman, precious steward, precious general, and other various kinds of excellent clothing, maá¹‡i jewels, pearls, gold, silver, coral, and beryl, which are valuable treasures?

Even if those poor people were to encounter and obtain them, they would be ashamed and unable to enjoy them. Even if they were to sell them, they would not know their value. They would ask for a very small price and give them away immediately in response. Or, because they have no discernment regarding the treasures, they would become disgusted and abandon them.
SubhÅ«ti should know!
Not only do those poor people not understand the value of the treasures, they also do not know the names of the treasures.
Thus it is, Ananda!

Only the Dharma sons of the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, or the sravakas who have already seen the truth and seek great bodhi, or the true and pure good friends who uphold it, are able to believe and accept this treasure of the Dharma.

They deeply respect and love the Dharma treasure that accords with the emptiness that cannot be obtained, and are also able to enjoy the principle teachings that accord with the true and pure Buddha Dharma, and are also able to practice the bodhisattva practices of non-attachment and non-clinging to all dharmas.
Ananda should know!

The poor and lowly sentient beings, namely those who lack the right hearing and those whose right hearing is destroyed, are ignorant and eyeless, how can they hope for the treasure of the right Dharma?
Even if they encounter and obtain it, they do not know how to respect and value it, but despise it towards other sentient beings and sell it, or despise it in their minds and abandon it.
Furthermore, Ananda!

Whether they are caá¹‡á¸Älas, pukkasa, craftsmen, or other poor and lowly people who make a living through evil means, they will never be able to seek much wealth and precious treasures. Even if they encounter and obtain them, they will not enjoy using them themselves, but will immediately sell them to others for a small price, or become disgusted with them and abandon them.
Ä€nanda should know!
The caá¹‡á¸Älas and others are a synonym for all non-Buddhists, and also for the disciples of non-Buddhists;

The other foolish, ordinary people who make a living through evil means are a synonym for those who are always mired in the mud of evil views, who at all times engage in practices based on grasping, who engage in practices bound by the characteristics of pleasure, who engage in practices with characteristics, who go beyond the proper path in all their pursuits, who are unable to seek the wealth and treasures of the holy Dharma, who even if they encounter and obtain them are unable to enjoy using them, who either deeply detest and abandon them or despise them and give them to others.
Ä€nanda should know!

If the Buddha's disciples practice the Buddha's way, in order to uphold the TathÄgata's boundless Buddha-dharmas such as the ten powers and four fearlessnesses, they seek to obtain such a treasury of profound Dharma treasures.

Regarding such a treasury of profound Dharma treasures, they give rise to the thought of true treasures, deeply cherish them, skillfully enjoy them, and diligently guard them, preventing them from being lost or destroyed.
Ä€nanda, you should know!
The lion's roar cannot be learned by foxes, only the offspring of the lion king can learn to roar like that.
Ä€nanda, you should know!

As for the foxes, they are likened to those with wrong views, foolish people, and ordinary beings. They definitely cannot diligently and skillfully learn the lion's roar of the Great Teacher's perfect enlightenment. Only the Buddha's disciples born from the wisdom of perfect enlightenment can diligently learn the lion's roar of the Great Teacher's perfect enlightenment. In this way, the Buddha's disciples are well able to enjoy the unsurpassed Dharma wealth of perfect enlightenment.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How marvelous!
The TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One is able to gather such a pure assembly.
How rare!

The TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One is able to gather such an excellent assembly, a spontaneous assembly, an unyielding assembly, an adamantine assembly that does not move, does not turn, and is not disturbed, to expound the perfection of wisdom.
At that time, the World-Honored One told ÅšÄriputra:
You are very good at praising the merits of the assembly.
Then, ÅšÄriputra said to the Buddha:
The merits of the assembly are not something I can praise.
Why is it so?
This assembly has accomplished immeasurable and boundless merits, like the majestic Mount Sumeru, which cannot be fully praised.
Then the Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:ğŸ”½So it is!
So it is!
As you have said.
The assembly here has accomplished boundless, pure, rare, and excellent merits. Even the World-Honored Buddhas cannot fully praise them, let alone other sentient beings.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

This assembly is not gathered by the power of the World-Honored Buddha, nor does the TathÄgata have any desire to gather this assembly. They have come to gather here because they have heard my name through the power of their own good roots.

Moreover, this great assembly has not come for the sake of the Buddha, nor has it been summoned by the TathÄgata's spiritual powers. They have come here because they have been awakened by the power of their own good roots.

Moreover, it is the way of the Dharma that if the World-Honored Buddha wishes to expound such profound and wonderful teachings, there will definitely be such great bodhisattvas who come to gather from the lands of the buddhas.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

The buddhas, the world-honored ones, whether past, future, or present, in the worlds of the ten directions, when they wish to reveal the subtle and profound Dharma of the bodhisattva canon that cuts off all doubts, must have such an assembly of immeasurable and boundless supreme and pure merits.

If there is such an assembly of immeasurable and boundless supreme and pure merits, they will certainly expound such a Dharma of the bodhisattva canon that cuts off all doubts and is subtle and profound.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva SubÄhu:

If one can reach far to the true nature of dharmas, this is called prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Such prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is subtle and profound, and cannot truly be spoken of.

Now, in accordance with the conventional expressions that you understand, I will skillfully expound the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, enabling the assembly of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas to hear and then skillfully and diligently study and practice it.
SubhÅ«ti!ğŸ”½The form aggregate is not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
apart from the form aggregate, it is also not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and apart from the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness, it is also not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

The other shore of the form aggregate is not the form aggregate itself, and the other shore of the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also not the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness themselves.
Just as the other shore of the form aggregate, the form aggregate is also like this;
just as the other shore of the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness, the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also like this.

Here, the other shore of the form aggregate is not the form aggregate itself, which is said to be the disjunction of the form aggregate;

the other shore of the feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness aggregates is also not the feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness aggregates themselves, which are said to be the disjunction of the feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness aggregates.

As for the other shore of the form aggregate being the same as the form aggregate, it is said that the intrinsic nature of the form aggregate is thus, and it is said that the intrinsic nature of the form aggregate as it really is and as it really exists is ultimately unobtainable;

as for the other shore of the feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness aggregates being the same as the feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness aggregates, it is said that the intrinsic nature of the feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness aggregates is thus, and it is said that the intrinsic nature of the feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness aggregates as they really are and as they really exist is ultimately unobtainable.
As for the intrinsic nature of the form aggregate as it really is and as it really exists being ultimately unobtainable, one should know that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is also like this;
Just as the nature of the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness is ultimately unobtainable, you should know that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is also like this.

The eye sense base is not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases are also not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;
apart from the eye sense base it is not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, apart from the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases it is also not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

The other shore of the eye sense base is not the eye sense base itself, the other shore of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases is also not the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases themselves.
Just as the other shore of the eye sense base, the eye sense base is also like this;
just as the other shore of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases, the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases are also like this.

Here, the other shore of the eye sense base is not the eye sense base itself, it is said that the eye sense base is free from attachment;

the other shore of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases is not the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases themselves, it is said that the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases are free from attachment.

As the other shore of the eye sense base, so is the eye sense base itself, it is said that the self-nature of the eye sense base is like this, then it is said that the eye sense base is the nature of things as they are, with an essential nature that cannot be apprehended;

as the other shore of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases, so are the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases themselves, it is said that the self-nature of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases is like this, then it is said that the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases are the nature of things as they are, with an essential nature that cannot be apprehended.
As the eye sense base is the nature of things as they are, with an essential nature that cannot be apprehended, one should know that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is also like this;

The form sense base is not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma sense bases are also not prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ;

just as the other shore of the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma sense bases, the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma sense bases are also like this.

just as the other shore of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense fields, the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense fields are also like this.

What is the term for true nature?
Good son!
The true nature of dharmas is not attained by foolish ordinary beings, nor is it different from them.

However, the nature of dharmas is seen by the TathÄgatas and their disciples, the Bodhisattvas. This nature of dharmas is the true principle, always unchanging, and is therefore called true nature. This true nature is called the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ of the Bodhisattvas.

They do not grasp at even the slightest attainment or clinging, let alone transgressions of the precepts.
These bodhisattvas do not fall into the three realms, nor do they fall into the various destinies, birth and death, or become attached to body and life, let alone external objects.
They have reached the end of the flow of birth and death, crossed the great ocean, and overcome the great difficulties.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
This assembly of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, relying on such dharmas and practicing the characteristics of all realms, knows that all realms are devoid of the nature of realms.
For this reason, these good people have no attachment to any realm.
Like the lion king, they are not attached to any realm. These good people are unstained and unmixed with regard to all realms, transcending all realms.
Like the leader of a great caravan, they are unimpeded. These good people, relying on such dharmas and practicing the characteristics of all realms, are without attachment.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
I do not see anyone in this great assembly of bodhisattvas who does not deeply believe and understand this Dharma, who is doubtful or uncertain about this Dharma.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
In this assembly, all bodhisattvas have already permanently severed doubts and uncertainties regarding this Dharma.
These good people themselves are free from doubt and uncertainty regarding this Dharma, and they are also able to permanently sever all sentient beings' doubts and uncertainties.

Because of this cause and condition, these good people are not doubtful or uncertain about any Dharma, and they are able to definitively proclaim for sentient beings that the nature of all dharmas is completely nonexistent.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!

In the future, if there are those who hear this kind of Dharma, they will also be able to sever doubts and uncertainties regarding all dharmas, and they will also be able to permanently sever all sentient beings' doubts and uncertainties, proclaiming for them the essential Dharma that I am now teaching.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
I will never say that those with meager wholesome roots can deeply believe and understand this Dharma;
Those with meager wholesome roots cannot accept this Dharma, and such a Dharma treasure cannot be used by them.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
Those with meager wholesome roots will not even hear the name of such a Dharma, let alone be able to uphold it, contemplate it, and cultivate it!

If there are those who hear such a Dharma, I will definitely predict that they will attain the Buddha's Dharma, that they will in the future world roar the lion's roar of the Buddha's Dharma, just as I now roar the lion's roar in the great assembly, a fearless roar, the roar of a great man, the roar of natural wisdom.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

If there are those who hear such profound essential teachings as these, even if they are able to arouse a single mind of faith and joy without giving rise to slander, I will also predict that they will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
Because it is extremely difficult to find sentient beings who, upon hearing the profound Dharma, joyfully believe and accept it.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

If sentient beings, upon hearing the profound Dharma, deeply give rise to faith and joy, and are able to give rise to the mind of unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, I say that those sentient beings are extremely difficult to find, and they have accomplished vast wholesome roots, possess great provisions, and don the great armor, quickly realizing unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

If sentient beings, upon hearing the explanation of such profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, joyfully believe and enjoy it and listen to it repeatedly, the blessings they will obtain are immeasurable and boundless, let alone being able to uphold it and expound it for others!

Even if they have not yet entered or have already entered the certainty of liberation, if they are not determined in the two vehicles, I predict that they will attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, benefiting and bringing happiness to sentient beings, forever ending without interruption.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
If sentient beings accomplish inferior dharmas, I do not see that they have the meaning of accepting vast dharmas. Vast dharmas refer to the Buddha's enlightenment.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

Among the various types of sentient beings, there are many who accomplish inferior dharmas. Their faith and understanding is also inferior, and they are unable to plant vast wholesome roots. They are unable to believe and accept such profound, vast, and undefiled true Dharma.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
If sentient beings accomplish vast dharmas, their faith and understanding will also be vast. They will set out on the
Great Vehicle, skillfully accomplish tasks, skillfully don armor, and be well able to discern the profound meaning and principle.
They will skillfully practice the great path, which is free from danger and is straightforward, far removed from dense forests, and has an equal appearance.
It is free from thorns, tiles, pebbles, and pits, is pure and unpolluted, and is neither crooked nor twisted.
benefiting the world, bringing peace and happiness to the world, and taking pity on the world, together with the gods,
humans, and others, creating vast meaning, benefits, and peace and happiness, providing all beings with a great and bright ladder,
endowed with great compassion and pity for all, wishing to bring benefit to all beings,
wishing to bestow peace and happiness, wishing to bring them peace and security, universally bestowing all beings with the requisites of peace and happiness,
such beings are bodhisattvas.
These mahÄsattvas are well able to enjoy the great Dharma treasures, these mahÄsattvas are well able to seek the great Dharma treasures, the most excellent treasures belong to them, not to others.
Why is it so?

If there are beings who do not associate with good friends, have not planted good roots, and have little merit and virtue, due to their inferior faith and understanding, they are unable to believe and accept such vast, profound, and undefiled true Dharma.
I rely on the distinctions among these beings to speak with a hidden meaning, saying:
The various distinctions in the realm of sentient beings, according to their superior or inferior types, each have their own preferences.
The class of sentient beings with inferior faith and understanding still enjoy sentient beings with inferior faith and understanding;
The class of sentient beings with vast faith and understanding still enjoy sentient beings with vast faith and understanding.

At that time, the World-Honored One told the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva SubÄhu:

Moreover, SubhÅ«ti!
What is called error is precisely falsehood, that which is clung to by foolish ordinary beings.
Such dharmas are not as they are, such clinging is not as its characteristics are, therefore it is called error and what is not real.
Therefore, bodhisattvas do not engage in perversion or falsity. For this reason, bodhisattvas are called speakers of truth and are also said to be practitioners without perversion.
If there is no perversion, then there is nothing to practice. Therefore, it is said that bodhisattvas practice non-practice. The cessation of all practices is called the practice of bodhisattvas.

Because bodhisattvas cease all practices and practice the practice of bodhisattvas. That is to say, they cease the practices of ordinary beings, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and those attached to grasping and practice the practice of bodhisattvas.

In this way, bodhisattvas also do not practice the Buddha's teachings, and do not grasp onto this as the Buddha's teachings, by the Buddha's teachings, in the Buddha's teachings, or belonging to the Buddha's teachings.
In the same way, bodhisattvas also do not engage in any conceptualization or differentiation, that is, bodhisattvas do not engage in conceptualization or differentiation.
Cutting off all conceptualization and differentiation is called the practice of bodhisattvas.
Good son!

Conceptualization refers to conceptualizing the intrinsic nature of dharmas, and differentiation refers to conceptualizing the distinctions among dharmas. It is not the case that all dharmas can be conceptualized or differentiated.

Because all dharmas cannot be conceptualized or differentiated. If one conceptualizes dharmas, then one differentiates them. However, all dharmas are far removed from conceptualization and differentiation.
Moreover, good son!
Conceptualization is called one extreme, and differentiation is the second extreme. It is not the case that bodhisattvas practice extremes or non-extremes.

If bodhisattvas do not engage with either the finite or the infinite, those bodhisattvas also do not see the middle. If one sees the middle, one engages with the middle. If one engages with the middle, one engages with the extremes. Because there is no engagement, manifestation, or indication in the middle, it is beyond the characteristics of engagement.

What is called the middle should be known as the eightfold noble path.
In this way, the noble path does not attain anything at all in all dharmas, yet it is present. In this way, the noble path does not see anything at all in all dharmas, yet it is present.
Moreover, SuvikrÄntavikrÄmin!
When there is no cultivation and no abandonment of dharmas, that is called the path of cessation.
This path of cessation does not cultivate or abandon anything at all in all dharmas, and it transcends cultivation and abandonment. It realizes the equality of the true nature of all dharmas.
By realizing the equality of the true nature of all dharmas, even the notion of the path does not exist, let alone seeing the path.

Moreover, good and courageous one!

If there is cultivation and sending away, there should be something attained, which is not called sending away. Here, sending away refers to sending away the nature of cultivation. Because there is no cultivation here, it is called sending away. Because cultivation is non-existent, sending away is also non-existent. Although it is said like this, it is not as it is said.

It refers to the inverted dharmas that do not arise again, and the unreal dharmas that do not arise again.

The assembly of bodhisattvas accords with the realization of all dharmas being free from inversions.

The assembly of bodhisattvas understands that inversions are all unreal, that is to say, within inversions there is no nature of inversion.

Because of understanding that inversions are truly non-existent, and because within inversions there is no nature of inversion, it is said that bodhisattvas accord with the realization of all dharmas being free from inversions.
Because of realizing that all dharmas are free from inversions, one no longer generates inversions towards dharmas;
if in this there are no further inversions, then with regard to this dharma one also has no practice.
