O Well-Intentioned One!
All inversions have something to be practiced. Because there is something to be practiced, there is arising. What is practiced and what arises are all due to inversions and false discrimination.

The assembly of bodhisattvas, with regard to the dharmas that are practiced, are all without discrimination and also without arising. Therefore, it is said that they are far removed from the inverted views.

Because of being without inverted views, then there is nothing practiced. Because of nothing practiced, then there is nothing that arises. Therefore, it is said that the bodhisattvas practice without practicing.

Nothing practiced means with regard to all dharmas, there is absolutely nothing practiced. Also, one does not contemplate and also does not manifest the characteristics of practicing. Therefore, it is said that the bodhisattvas practice without practicing.

These dharmas are all dependent, moving, discursive, and inclined towards craving, namely, I can engage in such movement, I engage in such discourse in this, I incline towards such by means of this engagement, I depend on this engagement in such dependence.

Here, the bodhisattva understands that all reliance, agitation, conceptual proliferation, and attachment to desirable objects harm all ignorance, and without relying on anything, there is no reliance at all, and therefore nothing to practice or hoard;
because of not hoarding, there is no bondage or liberation, and nothing to initiate or give rise to.
In this way, the bodhisattva, having eliminated all reliance, practices the perfection of wisdom.

The assembly of bodhisattvas does not give rise to attachment to these various Dharma gates. They know the inverted thoughts and mental factors that arise in sentient beings. In all situations, they never give rise to inverted thoughts, and they also do not give rise to various inversions based on the mind.
Why is this?
Good and brave one!

The assembly of bodhisattvas practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, is far removed from inverted thoughts and mental factors, realizes the fundamentally pure and clear nature of the mind, and in it there is absolutely no arising of mind and mental factors.
Good and brave one!
Foolish ordinary beings, based on the objects they perceive, give rise to mind and mental factors. They grasp at the existence of objects and grasp at the existence of all mind and mental factors.
The assembly of bodhisattvas knows that those objects and the mind and mental factors that arise from them are absolutely non-existent. Therefore, they do not give rise to mind and mental factors.

The bodhisattva observes in this way that all mental and mental factors are originally pure in their intrinsic nature, originally clear and bright, but foolish people give rise to defilements through delusion and inversion. He further thinks:

'The mind and mental factors arise due to the objective realm. Because the objective realm is known to be nonexistent, the mind and mental factors cannot arise. Since they do not arise, there is also no abiding or cessation.
The mind and mental factors are originally clear and pure, free from all defilements, pure and delightful.
The nature of the mind does not arise, nor does it abide or cease. It also does not cause dharmas to have arising, abiding, etc., but foolish people mistakenly grasp at these things.'
In this way, the bodhisattva knows that the mind and mental factors are originally unborn, do not abide or cease, and cultivates the perfection of wisdom.
If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, it is practicing the perfection of wisdom.
When practicing in this way, they do not think like this:
'I practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, I now rely on this to practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, I now do this to practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, I now come from this to practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.'
If bodhisattvas think like this:
'This is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, this is due to prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, this relies on prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, this belongs to prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.'
They do not practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ because of this thought.
If bodhisattvas have no view and no attainment regarding all prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄs, and practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, this is practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

The profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ practiced by bodhisattvas is the ground of the virtues such as the four forms of fearlessness of the tathÄgatas, the arhats, the perfectly enlightened ones.ğŸ”½The assembly of bodhisattvas practicing the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, by being able to realize the four forms of fearlessness and so forth, takes them as their activity.

If bodhisattvas have not yet realized unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, by the power of great vows or the power of being upheld by the tathÄgatas, practicing the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they will quickly be able to embrace boundless virtues such as the four forms of fearlessness.

ÅšrÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas are unable to aspire to the buddhas' virtues such as the four forms of fearlessness. The world-honored buddhas also do not protect and uphold them, enabling them to realize the four forms of fearlessness and so forth.

The assembly of bodhisattvas, by the power of great vows and the power of the TathÄgatas' support, will be able to attain the four forms of fearlessness and so forth. Why is this?
Good and courageous one!
The assembly of bodhisattvas practicing the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ will definitely be able to attain the four forms of unobstructed understanding.
What are called the four forms of unobstructed understanding?

The unobstructed understanding of meaning, the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, the unobstructed understanding of language, and the unobstructed understanding of eloquence. These are called the four forms of unobstructed understanding.

The assembly of bodhisattvas who have accomplished these four forms of unobstructed understanding, although they have not yet attained the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment that they seek, by the power of their great vows, they are able to embrace the qualities of the buddhas such as the four forms of fearlessness.

The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, knowing that they have accomplished the four unobstructed understandings and the supreme wholesome roots, knowing that they have attained the stage of the merit of the profound perfection of wisdom, with their supernormal powers diligently protect and think of them, enabling them to embrace the merits of the Buddhas such as the four forms of fearlessness. Therefore, if bodhisattvas wish to seek and attain the four unobstructed understandings, and wish to embrace the merits and wholesome roots such as the four forms of fearlessness, they should study the perfection of wisdom and practice the perfection of wisdom, and should not give rise to attachment.

All inverted dharmas are all unreal, all dharmas arise from inversion, all inversions are all without real nature.

SubhÅ«ti!
Because all dharmas are all devoid of self-nature, seeking self-nature is all unobtainable, therefore they are all characterized by non-nature.

Non-nature is unreal and unborn, therefore it is called non-nature.
This then reveals that nature is not really existent, therefore it is called non-nature. If nature does not exist, then it cannot be cultivated and also cannot be eliminated.
Because that which arises from inversion is not really existent, since it cannot be cultivated and also cannot be eliminated, why is it so?

Because all dharmas have non-nature as their nature, being far removed from self-nature are not real things, not being real things there is nothing to cultivate and nothing to eliminate.

Why is it so?
Good and brave one!
Because all dharmas cannot be grasped, cannot be clung to, cannot be grasped after, and cannot be clung to after.
Why is it so?
Good and brave one!
There is not a single dharma that can be grasped, nor is there a single dharma that can grasp.
Why is this?
Both that which grasps and that which is grasped are both unobtainable.
Why is this?
Good son!
Because all dharmas are not solid, like illusory things;
Because all dharmas are not autonomous, the nature of solidity cannot be obtained;
Because all dharmas are like light and shadow, they cannot be grasped;
Because all dharmas are all false and deceptive, they have no self-nature;
Because all dharmas are like foam, they cannot be grasped;ğŸ”½Because all dharmas arise and quickly cease, they are like floating bubbles;
Because all dharmas arise from delusion, they are like mirages;
Because all dharmas are like plantains, they have no solid core;
Because all dharmas are like the moon in the water, they cannot be grasped;
Because all dharmas are like rainbows, being false discriminations;
Because all dharmas are without activity, being unable to initiate;
Because all dharmas are like empty fists, being without real nature and characteristics.
Good son!
The bodhisattvas, having thus contemplated all dharmas, have no grasping, no attachment, no abiding, and no clinging to any dharma.
Good son!

If bodhisattvas train like this, they do not take past form as practice, future form as practice, or present form as practice, and they also do not take past sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas as practice, future [sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas] as practice, or present [sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas] as practice.
SubhÅ«ti!

If bodhisattvas train like this, they do not take past eye consciousness, future eye consciousness, or present eye consciousness as a basis for practice, and they also do not take past, future, or present ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind consciousness as a basis for practice.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti,

if bodhisattvas are able to practice like this, although they contemplate the past with the aspects of emptiness, quiescence, and non-self, they do not practice the past with the aspects of emptiness, quiescence, and non-self;
although they contemplate the future with the aspects of emptiness, quiescence, and non-self, they do not practice the future with the aspects of emptiness, quiescence, and non-self;
although they contemplate the present with the aspects of emptiness, quiescence, and non-self, they do not practice the present with the aspects of emptiness, quiescence, and non-self.
SubhÅ«ti,

If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, although they contemplate the past as empty, without self, without what belongs to a self, impermanent, unstable, and not abiding in an unchanging way, they do not practice in this way with regard to the past;

although they contemplate the future as empty, without self, without what belongs to a self, impermanent, unstable, and not abiding in an unchanging way, they do not practice in this way with regard to the future;

although they contemplate the present as empty, without self, without what belongs to a self, impermanent, unstable, and not abiding in an unchanging way, they do not practice in this way with regard to the present.
SubhÅ«ti!
If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way and able to abide in this way, they will quickly perfect the practice of the perfection of wisdom.
SubhÅ«ti!
If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, all evil mÄras will be unable to take advantage of them.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, they will be able to fully understand all demonic activities and will not be led astray by any demonic activities.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, then they do not take form as an object, nor do they take feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness as an object;
They do not take the eye as an object, nor do they take the ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind as an object;
They do not take form as an object, nor do they take sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas as an object;
They do not take eye-consciousness as an object, nor do they take ear-, nose-, tongue-, body-, or mind-consciousness as an object;
They do not take name-and-form as an object, nor do they take defilement or purity as an object, nor do they take inverted views, obscurations,
or the practice of craving as an object, nor do they take greed, anger, or delusion as an object, nor do they take self, sentient beings, and so forth as an object, nor do they
take annihilation or permanence as an object, nor do they take the limited or the limitless as an object, nor do they take desire, form, or the formless realm as an object,
does not take the realm of dependent arising as its object, does not take the realms of earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness as its object,
does not take the realms of sentient beings and dharmas as its object, does not take the real and the false as its object,
does not take the severed and the unsevered as its object, does not take the severing of greed, hatred, and delusion as its object, does not take
giving, stinginess, morality, immorality, patience, anger, diligence, laziness,
meditative concentration, distraction, wisdom, and ignorance as its object, does not take the applications of mindfulness, right

efforts, bases of supernatural powers, faculties, powers, factors of awakening, and factors of the path as its object, does not take the severing of the inverted views, etc. as its object, does not take the meditative concentrations, liberations, samÄdhis, and samÄpattis as its object, does not take loving-kindness,
compassion, joy, and equanimity as its object, does not take suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path as its object, does not take the knowledge of destruction,
the knowledge of non-arising, and the knowledge of non-fabrication as its object, does not take the knowledge of non-attachment as its object, does not take the ordinary person
the stages of the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas, do not take ordinary beings, Å›rÄvakas,
pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas as objects, do not take supernormal knowledge and insight as objects, do not take

liberation as an object, do not take the insight of liberation as an object, do not take nirvÄá¹‡a as an object, do not take the insight of knowledge of the past, future, and present as an object, do not take the knowledge, powers, and fearlessnesses of a buddha as objects, do not take the purification of a buddha land
as an object, do not take the purification of the major and minor marks as an object, do not take the perfection of Å›rÄvakas as an object, do not take the perfection of pratyekabuddhas
as an object, do not take the perfection of bodhisattvas as an object.
Why is it so?
Good and brave one!
Because all dharmas are not objects, because all dharmas are not subjects, and because all dharmas are not grasped, one can speak of objects in them.
Good and brave one!
If there is an object, then there is activity, attachment, and grasping. If there is grasping, then there is worry, suffering, sharp sorrow, and lamentation.
Good son!
If there is an object, then there is bondage, no path of liberation, and thus all worry and suffering increase.
Good son!

If there is an object, then there is reliance, movement, and idle speculation. If there is an object, then there are various disputes and disagreements. If there is an object, then there are various kinds of ignorance and delusion. If there is an object, then there is fear. If there is an object, then there are the snares of Mara and the bonds of Mara. If there is an object, then there is suffering and the seeking of happiness.
Good son!

The bodhisattva sees these various faults and does not take objects. Because there are no objects, he does not grasp at any dharmas. Because there is nothing to grasp, he abides without attachment to any dharmas.
In this way, although bodhisattvas have no objects, they attain mastery over the sense fields. Although they attain mastery over the sense fields, they have no reliance or dwelling.
Good son!
If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, they will be able to not grasp at any phenomena, be without attachment, and without disputes. They will abide in non-attachment to all phenomena.
Good son!
These bodhisattvas will attain liberation from all conditioned phenomena and practice the perfection of wisdom.
Good son!

If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way and abide in this way, they will quickly perfect the practice of the perfection of wisdom. No evil mÄras will be able to obstruct them, and the mÄra-demons will not be able to possess them. Those who seek their weaknesses will never be able to find them, and they will also not be able to disturb them with skillful means;

And yet they are able to subdue MÄra and his army, and are able to fully awaken to all demonic activities, not acting freely in accordance with demonic activities, and shaking and burning the palaces of MÄra;
They are also able to subdue all non-Buddhists, and are not subdued by non-Buddhists;
They are also able to destroy all other teachings, and are not destroyed by other teachings.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!

If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, then they do not abide in discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding form, and they also do not abide in discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness;
They do not abide in discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding the eye, and they also do not abide in discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind;
They do not abide in discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding form, and they also do not abide in discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas;
They do not dwell in discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding eye consciousness, and likewise for ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.
For this reason, these bodhisattvas do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding names and forms;
They do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding defilement and purity, and do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding dependent arising;

They do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding the four inverted views, the five hindrances, and the six kinds of craving, and do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding annihilationism and eternalism;
They do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding the realms of desire, form, and formlessness;

They do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding the realms of sentient beings and dharmas, and do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding greed, hatred, and delusion;
They do not give rise to discrimination or nondiscrimination regarding truth and falsehood;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the elements of earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding bondage and liberation;

They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the various concepts of self, sentient beings, life, birth, nurturing, person, pudgala, mind-born, youth, doer, experiencer, knower, seer, and so forth;

They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding generosity and stinginess, morality and immorality, patience and anger, diligence and laziness, concentration and distraction, wisdom and ignorance;

They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the applications of mindfulness, right efforts, bases of supernatural powers, faculties, powers, factors of awakening, and factors of the path;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the abandonment of the inverted views and so forth;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the meditative absorptions, liberations, samÄdhis, and samÄpattis;

They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, and they do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the cognition of exhaustion, the cognition of non-arising, and the cognition of non-fabrication;

They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the stages of ordinary beings, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas, and they do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the dharmas of ordinary beings, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas;

They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the cognition and vision of the supernormal powers, and they do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the cognition and vision of the past, future, and present;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the cognition and vision of non-attachment;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding illumination and liberation;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding liberation and the wisdom and insight of liberation;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the wisdom, powers, and fearlessnesses of the buddhas;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the purity of the marks;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the purity of the buddha-lands;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the perfection of the Å›rÄvakas;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the perfection of the pratyekabuddhas;
They do not give rise to discrimination or differentiation regarding the perfection of the bodhisattvas.
Why is it so?
Good son!
If there is discrimination, then there is differentiation. If there is no discrimination here, then there is no differentiation here.

All foolish ordinary beings are entirely arisen from discrimination. Those thoughts all arise from different discriminations. Therefore, bodhisattvas do not give rise to discrimination, nor do they have different discriminations.
SubhÅ«ti!

What is called discrimination is one extreme, and different discrimination is a second extreme. If one does not give rise to discrimination or different discrimination in this place, then in this place one is far removed from the two extremes and there is no middle either.
SubhÅ«ti!
If one says there is a middle, that is also discrimination. Discrimination of the middle is also said to be an extreme.
If in this place there is discrimination, then in this place there will be different discrimination. For this reason, there is no meaning of cutting off discrimination and different discrimination;

if in this place there is no discrimination, then in this place there will be no different discrimination. For this reason, there is the meaning of cutting off discrimination and different discrimination.
SubhÅ«ti!
As for the elimination of discrimination, it means that in this [realm] there is nothing at all to be eliminated.
Why is it so?
Good and courageous one!

Because of the power of non-existence, falsehood, discrimination, and different discriminations giving rise to reversals, when they are tranquil, reversals also do not exist. Because of the absence of reversals, there is absolutely nothing to be eliminated.
Good and courageous one!

Know that the expression elimination of suffering indicates the increase in words about the elimination of suffering, which means that in this [realm] there is no small amount of suffering to be eliminated, and therefore it is called the elimination of suffering.

If the intrinsic nature of suffering had even a little reality that could be eliminated, but because the intrinsic nature of suffering has not even a little reality, there is nothing to be eliminated. It is only the view of the non-existence of suffering that is called the elimination of suffering, which means that because the intrinsic nature of suffering is completely known to be unobtainable in even the slightest way, it is called the elimination of suffering.
Those who have no discrimination or different discriminations regarding suffering are said to have the tranquility of suffering, which is the meaning of causing suffering not to arise.
Good and courageous one!
If bodhisattvas can see in this way, then they will not give rise to discrimination or different discriminations regarding all dharmas.
Good at mental application!
This is called the bodhisattvas' thorough knowledge of the nature of discrimination and different discriminations, and the practice of the perfection of wisdom.
Good at mental application!

If bodhisattvas can practice in this way and abide in this way, the practice of the perfection of wisdom will quickly be fulfilled. All evil mÄras will not be able to obstruct them. They will be able to perceive all the activities instigated by the mÄra hordes. In all their endeavors, they will not be controlled by the mÄra affairs and will naturally cause the evil mÄras to retreat and scatter. They will crush the mÄra hordes, causing them to gradually diminish. Their bodies and minds will be at ease, free from all fear, and the evil mÄra hordes will not be able to disturb them.
They will put an end to all the causes for going to evil destinies and block the many wrong paths in the world.
Free from all darkness, they will cross over the turbulent currents and attain the pure eye of all dharmas.
They become a great light for sentient beings, continuing the Buddha's lineage and preventing its extinction.
They realize the true path and the equality of the path, and with compassion for sentient beings, they give rise to the pure Dharma eye;

They are fully endowed with diligence and free from laziness, they attain patient acceptance and are far from thoughts of anger, they enter excellent meditative absorption without any basis, they attain true wisdom and accomplish penetrating insight, they dispel regret and are far from the entanglements of hindrances, they emerge from the evil demon's snares and sever the nets of craving, they abide in right mindfulness without any forgetfulness.
They attain pure precepts and reach the shore of pure precepts.
They abide in merit and are free from faults.
They attain the power of concentration and wisdom that cannot be shaken, and all other teachings cannot subdue them.
They attain the purity of all dharmas and are never lost, and they proclaim the Dharma with fearlessness.
They enter the great assemblies without any timidity, and they bestow the wondrous Dharma without any secrecy or stinginess.
With the equal path, they purify all paths, and they vow to abandon the wrong paths and cultivate what should be cultivated.
With pure dharmas, they perfume what should be perfumed, and with pure wisdom, they purify what should be purified.
Their capacity and depth are vast like the great ocean, still and unmoving, difficult to fathom, and the ocean of Dharma is boundless, surpassing all measurements.
Good and Brave One!

If bodhisattvas are able to practice like this, they will accomplish these and other boundless merits. Such merits are difficult to fathom their limits. Except for the World-Honored Buddha, no one can know them.
Furthermore, Good and Brave One!

If bodhisattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ like this, their wonderful appearance will not diminish, their wealth and status will not diminish, their retinue will not diminish, their kind will not diminish, their family will not diminish, their country will not diminish;
They will not be born in border regions, will not encounter unfavorable conditions, will not live with defiled and evil beings, and will also not be close to impure activities;
Their own minds will not regress, and their wisdom will not diminish;
They listen to and accept various Dharma gates from others, and are all able to enter into the equal nature of dharmas;
They perpetuate the Buddha's lineage and the wisdom of omniscience, causing it to always flourish without interruption;
They have attained the light of the Buddha's teachings and have attained proximity to the wisdom of omniscience.
If an evil mÄra comes to their place and wishes to disturb them, it will cause that mÄra and his retinue to all become ashes, their eloquence suddenly lost and their nets all severed;
Even if koá¹­is of mÄras and their armies all come to harass them, their minds will not waver.
Then the evil mÄras and their armies will be frightened and scatter, thinking this thought:

Now this bodhisattva has surpassed my realm. He will no longer act or abide in my realm, nor will he become attached to it, causing other sentient beings to all escape from my realm and attain liberation.
When the evil mÄras have had this thought, they will be sorrowful and lament to each other, saying:
'Now this bodhisattva has harmed our retinue and companions, depriving us of power.
' Having said this, each gave rise to sorrow, regret, and remorse.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
When a bodhisattva practices the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, cultivates the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and unifies with the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ,

at that time the palace of MÄra loses its majestic radiance, and everywhere gradually gives rise to the appearance of smoke and flames. The evil MÄra becomes frightened, sorrowful, and distressed, like being wounded by a knife or poisoned by an arrow. They all lament and say such words:
'Now this bodhisattva will cause sentient beings not to experience what we inflict upon them. Now this
bodhisattva will cause sentient beings to leave our realm. Now this bodhisattva will cause sentient beings to escape from
our realm. Now this bodhisattva will cause sentient beings not to dwell in our realm. Now this bodhisattva
Sarva will cause sentient beings to destroy the realm of self. Now this bodhisattva will cause sentient beings to destroy the net of self.

Now this bodhisattva will pull out sentient beings and cause them to forever emerge from the mire of desires,ğŸ”½Now this bodhisattva will cause sentient beings to escape from the net of views. Now this bodhisattva will cause sentient beings to emerge from the wrong paths covered by veils. Now
this bodhisattva will establish sentient beings and cause them to abide in the right path. Now
this bodhisattva will lead sentient beings and cause them to forever emerge from the thickets of views.'
SubhÅ«ti!
Those evil mÄras, seeing this bodhisattva with such supreme benefits, are sorrowful, suffering, and distressed, as if an arrow had pierced their hearts.
It is like a person who has lost a great treasure, accomplishing vast sorrow, suffering, and distress;
In the same way, the evil mÄras deeply regret and are sorrowful, suffering, and distressed, like being poisoned by an arrow, alarmed day and night, not enjoying their original seats.
Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
When a bodhisattva practices profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, cultivates profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and unifies with profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ,
at that time, all evil mÄras gather together in one place, contemplate expedient means, and wish to destroy the bodhisattva. They say to each other:
What strategy should we devise now, and what work should we do to destroy the correct practice cultivated by this bodhisattva?

At that time, the assembly of evil mÄras is filled with doubt, and is sorrowful and unhappy, like being poisoned by an arrow. They encourage each other to go to the place of the bodhisattva, wait for an opportunity to seek out his shortcomings, and manifest fearful events.

Because of the majestic power of this bodhisattva's practice of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, even if the assembly of evil mÄras exhausts their spiritual power, they will still be unable to move even a single hair of the bodhisattva, let alone cause the bodhisattva's body and mind to change.

At that time, the evil mÄras realize that the bodhisattvas are far removed from fear, horripilation, and other such things, and they devise various means to enchant them. However, because their minds are weak and fearful, none of their enchanting methods succeed.
At that time, the evil mÄra king thinks like this:
I am still unable to destroy this bodhisattva, let alone my retinue or others being able to destroy him!
Having thought this, he is frightened, his power exhausted and his plans exhausted. He returns to his own palace and dwells there in sorrow and worry.

In this way, the bodhisattva who practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ possesses great power. The evil mÄras and their retinue are still unable to cause his mind to be confused for even the duration of a finger snap, let alone be able to create other obstacles.
Good at Vigor!
In this way, the bodhisattva who practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ accomplishes such merits, wisdom, and greatly powerful spiritual abilities.

Even if all sentient beings in the trichiliocosm were to transform into MÄra, with each MÄra leading that many hordes of MÄra to the bodhisattva's place in order to disturb him, they would still be unable to obstruct the bodhisattva's cultivation of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ with all their spiritual powers.
Why is this?
Good and brave one!

At that time, the bodhisattva, having accomplished such a profound sword-like power of prajÃ±Ä, also accomplishes an inconceivable, immeasurable, and unequaled power of prajÃ±Ä, and is not subdued by any violent and evil MÄra armies.
Good and brave one!ğŸ”½The great sword is the sword of prajÃ±Ä;
The great sword is the sword of prajÃ±Ä;
The great power is the power of prajÃ±Ä.
Therefore, prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is not the realm of activity for any evil MÄra.
Furthermore, good and brave one!
The non-Buddhist sages who attain the four meditations and four formless concentrations transcend the realm of desire and MÄra, and are born in the BrahmÄ heavens and the four formless realms.
Even the mundane wisdom that the bodhisattvas always accomplish is not their domain, let alone the true prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ!
How much less could the evil MÄra practice this domain!
They are not even in the domain of the non-Buddhist sages who attain the wisdom of the meditations and formless concentrations, let alone prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ!
Good son!

When a bodhisattva accomplishes prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, at that time the bodhisattva is called one who has accomplished great power;ğŸ”½If one has accomplished the power of prajÃ±Ä, one is called one who has accomplished the sharp sword of wisdom;
If one has accomplished the sharpness of prajÃ±Ä, one is called one who has accomplished the sharp sword of wisdom.
The armies of evil MÄras cannot subdue them, but they can subdue all MÄra's armies.
Furthermore, good son!
If bodhisattvas accomplish the sharp sword of the perfection of wisdom and possess great power, these bodhisattvas have no basis in any place, and whatever they do is also without basis.
Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
If there is a basis, then there is movement. If there is movement, then there is agitation. If there is agitation, then there is conceptual proliferation.
SubhÅ«ti!
If sentient beings have a basis, move, are agitated, and conceptually proliferate, then these sentient beings follow the power of MÄra and have not escaped the realm of MÄra.
SubhÅ«ti!

If sentient beings, even if they are reborn in the highest heaven, have a basis, are bound to a basis, and depend on a place, they will certainly fall back into the realm of MÄra, have not escaped the net of the evil MÄra, and are always followed by the thread of the evil MÄra.

Like the son of MÄkandika and the son of Ä€rÄá¸a KÄlÄma, and all other non-Buddhist ascetics who rely on the formless realm, are bound to their support, and rely on their support and supported places.
Good and Brave One!
If bodhisattvas practice the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, cultivate the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and realize the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ,
these bodhisattvas will have no support in any place, and in all their actions they will also have no support.
Good and Brave One!

If bodhisattvas vigorously strive, practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and abide in accordance with it, at that time the bodhisattvas will not rely on form, nor will they rely on feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness;
they will not rely on the eye, nor will they rely on the ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind;
they will not rely on form, nor will they rely on sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas;
They do not rely on eye consciousness, nor do they rely on ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind consciousness;
They do not rely on name-and-form, nor do they rely on inverted views, entanglements,
or the various types of craving, nor do they rely on dependent origination, nor do they rely on the realms of desire, form, or formlessness;
They do not rely on the notions of self, sentient being, life, birth, nurture, person,
pudgala, mind-born, youth, doer, experiencer, knower,
or seer, nor do they rely on the elements of earth, water, fire, wind, space,
or consciousness, nor do they rely on the realms of sentient beings or phenomena, nor do they rely on the first meditative absorption
up to the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, nor do they rely on craving for existence, nor do they rely on craving for non-existence;
They do not rely on annihilation or permanence, nor do they rely on existence, nor do they rely on non-existence,
not relying on generosity, stinginess, upholding precepts, violating precepts, patience, anger
, diligence, laziness, meditative concentration, distraction, wisdom, and ignorance, not
relying on the applications of mindfulness, right efforts, bases of supernatural powers, faculties, powers, factors of awakening, factors of the path
, not relying on the elimination of inverted views, etc., not relying on meditative concentration, liberation, samÄdhi
, attainments, not relying on suffering, its origin, cessation, and the path, not relying on the knowledge of destruction
, the knowledge of non-arising, the knowledge of non-action, not relying on the view of non-attached knowledge, not relying
on illumination and liberation, not relying on the knowledge and vision of liberation, not relying on the stages of ordinary beings,
Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas, not relying on the dharmas of ordinary beings, Å›rÄvakas
, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas, not relying on nirvÄá¹‡a, not relying on transcendence
They do not rely on the cognition and insight of the past, future, and present, and do not rely on the equality of the three times,
They do not rely on the cognition, powers, fearlessness, etc. of the Buddha, and do not rely on the cognition of all cognition and insight,
They do not rely on the perfection of the major and minor marks, do not rely on the perfection of the Buddha land, do not rely on the perfection of the assembly of Å›rÄvakas,
Do not rely on the perfection of the assembly of bodhisattvas, do not rely on all dharmas, do not rely on
change and transformation, do not rely on movement and agitation, do not rely on conceptual proliferation.

Because of non-reliance, all are eliminated and dispelled. They do not even cling to the path of non-reliance. They do not even grasp and cling to non-reliance. They also do not attain this is reliance, they also do not attain abiding in this reliance, they also do not attain belonging to this reliance, they also do not attain relying on this reliance. They have no grasping and clinging to the relied upon.

In this way, bodhisattvas have no reliance, no attainment, no grasping, no fixation, no attachment, no dwelling, and are not tainted by any reliance. They are also unhindered by any reliance and realize the pure Dharma of all reliance.
Good son!

These bodhisattvas rely on all dharmas, relying on the pure and subtle wisdom-insight to cultivate prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ. For this reason, evil mÄras cannot take advantage of them, the hordes of evil mÄras cannot subdue them, and they are able to subdue all mÄra armies.
Furthermore, good son!

If bodhisattvas have not yet given rise to the mind of unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, they should first accumulate immeasurable and innumerable provisions of wholesome roots, make offerings to many buddhas, serve many good friends, ask about the essentials of the Dharma in the presence of many buddhas, give rise to great vows and be replete with aspiration, happily practice giving to sentient beings, greatly respect and uphold pure precepts, be replete with patience and gentleness, be vigorous and energetic, free from laziness, greatly respect and practice pure meditative absorption, and respectfully study and cultivate pure wisdom.

These bodhisattvas, having already given rise to the mind of unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, should further diligently study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and with the power of wisdom subdue the hosts of mÄras.
They should always think like this:
Do not let evil mÄras seek out my shortcomings and create disturbances.
By this power, they will prevent evil mÄras from finding an opportunity to obstruct their studies, and also prevent the mÄra hordes from giving rise to the thought:
'I will wait for an opportunity to create disturbances and obstacles for this bodhisattva's practice.'
If such a thought arises, they will immediately realize:
'If I do this, I will certainly encounter great suffering.'
Because of this, they will give rise to a greatly terrified mind:
'Do not let me now lose my life and body, therefore I should put an end to this disturbed mind.'
Then the evil army of Mara will disappear.
Good and Brave One!
For this reason, the evil army of Mara will not be able to obstruct the bodhisattvas' study of the profound prajnaparamita.
Furthermore, Good and Brave One!

If bodhisattvas hear the teaching of prajnaparamita, they will give rise to pure desire and superior intention, deeply respect and praise its merits, and give rise to the thought of the great teacher;
Having heard the teachings associated with the six paramitas, they will also not give rise to doubt or confusion;
Hearing the profound Dharma, their minds are not confused or deluded, and they also do not give rise to doubt or uncertainty;

These bodhisattvas first purify their intention, and all their intentions are free from defilement. The evil mÄra armies are unable to obstruct them. Even if they seek an opportunity, they are unable to find one. They are able to be aware of all the activities of the mÄras. All the evil mÄras are unable to lead them astray. Good son!
For this reason, these bodhisattvas cannot be disturbed by the retinue of the evil mÄras.
Furthermore, good son!

If bodhisattvas are able to practice in this way, then they are neither united with nor separate from form, and also neither united with nor separate from feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness;

they are neither united with nor separate from form, and also neither united with nor separate from sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas;

or the various practices of craving; it is neither united nor separate from the realms of desire, form, or formlessness;

If it is separate, it is not combined with or separate from the stages of ordinary beings, hearers, solitary realizers, bodhisattvas, or buddhas.
It is not combined with or separate from the dharmas of ordinary beings, hearers, solitary realizers, bodhisattvas, or buddhas.

It is not combined with or separate from the perfection of solitary realizers. It is not combined with or separate from the perfection of bodhisattvas. Why is this?ğŸ”½Because,
Good and Brave One,
all dharmas are neither combined nor separate.

all dharmas do not appear in order to be combined or separated.
SubhÅ«ti!
Union means permanence, and separation means annihilation.
SubhÅ«ti!
The nature of all dharmas is not united or separated through realization.
SubhÅ«ti!
The nature of all dharmas does not manifest for the sake of union or separation.
SubhÅ«ti!

If the nature of all dharmas manifested for the sake of union or separation, then one would be able to find an agent, an instigator, an origination, an instigator of origination, an experiencer, an instigator of experience, a knower, an instigator of knowing, a seer, an instigator of seeing, a uniter, an instigator of union, a separator, or an instigator of separation, and the TathÄgata would also have to establish dharmas as this is the agent, the instigator, up to the separator, or the instigator of separation.
SubhÅ«ti!

Because the nature of dharmas is not present as either combined or separated, and because one cannot obtain even the slightest bit of a dharma that is created, has a creator, or is separated, or has a separator, the Buddha does not establish them.
Good son!
All dharmas arise from delusion. Delusion is neither combined nor separated. Why is this?
Good son!
The state of delusion cannot be obtained in the slightest, nor can the nature of true arising be obtained. Why is this?
Good son!
Delusion is not real, false, deceptive, empty, and nonexistent. There is not even the slightest real dharma within it that can be called delusion.
Good son!

Delusion confuses sentient beings and establishes sentient beings. The various kinds of sentient beings are manifested by false discrimination, causing sentient beings to give rise to vain reliance and attachment, agitation and frivolous discourse.
Good son!
It is like using an empty fist to deceive and delude a child, because they do not know and think there is a real object.
Foolish ordinary beings are also like this. They are deceived by false inversion, and falsely see the nature of combination and separation in all dharmas, considering it to be truly existent.

The deluded inversion of the ignorant is difficult to liberate from the non-real and the arising of the thought of real existence. Therefore, all foolish ordinary beings falsely see combination and separation, bound by inversion, running in birth and death, considering combination to be attainment, combination to be abiding, combination to be seeing, and combination to be grasping.
Because of the existence of combination, one then grasps at the existence of separation, considering the elimination of combination to be the attainment of separation.
Good son!

If there is combination in a place, there is separation in that place. If there is no attainment in combination, no reliance, and no arising of grasping and attachment, one also does not see separation.
Good son!
If there is attainment, reliance, and the arising of grasping and attachment in separation, then there is combination, and one is not yet able to be separated from the suffering of birth and death.
SubhÅ«ti!
These bodhisattvas, contemplating this meaning, are neither united nor separated from the nature of dharmas, and also do not act or study for the sake of uniting or separating with dharmas.
SubhÅ«ti!
These bodhisattvas thoroughly understand union and separation, and practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
SubhÅ«ti!
In this way, bodhisattvas abiding in prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ can quickly perfect the dharmas of omniscience.

All of these have shifting, reliance, agitation, practice, and observation. Bodhisattvas thoroughly know all of these, and no longer practice or observe within them.
Furthermore, good and brave one!
